text.tspan: Nominee takes two oaths of office:
Justice is a recess appointed justice,
Recess appointed justice term will end
Nominee is rejected and does not become
a Supreme Court justice, leaving vacancy
person a nominee, or a recess

line.style: fill: none; fill-opacity:0; stroke-width: 2; stroke-dasharray: 20; stroke: #000000
fill: none; fill-opacity:0; stroke-width: 2; stroke-dasharray: 20; stroke: #000000

text.tspan: The United States Constitution, Article II, Section 2, Clause 2
establishes the overall legal requirement of presidential
of Supreme Court justices, which this chart details.
Clause 3 provides the president the power of
recess appointment, when the Senate is officially in recess.
The Judiciary Act of 1869 specified that the
Supreme Court shall consist of nine justices:
one Chief Justice, and eight Associate Justices.
By law, any vacancies on the Court must therefore be filled.
The relevant language of the 1869 act, specifying the
size of the court, was codified as 28 U.S.C. § 1.
5 U.S.C. § 2902 specifies the manner in which presidential
commissions of federal officers are to be prepared.
This entails all judicial officers, which include the
Supreme Court. Additionally, 28 U.S.C. § 4 specifies that
precedence of justices is based upon date of commission,
not upon dates of oaths being taken. Nevertheless,
a nominee must take two oaths before becoming a justice.
5 U.S.C. § 3331 provides the text of the constitutional
oath, and requires its administration to a nominee.
Additionally, 28 U.S.C. § 453 provides the text of
the judicial oath, which all federal judges must take
before assuming office. Upon the presidential execution of
a commission, and the administration of both oaths,
the nominee is a Supreme Court justice.
